creator: gsmdib@gmail.com
text:
The scenario is as follows: I've got tomcat running at localhost:8180 and httpd 
at :80 and :443 serving http and https connections. What i want is to run 
tomcat behind https, that's quite natural. Here is the config for http:
<VirtualHost *>
        ServerName www.myhost.org
        <Location /confluence>
                ProxyPass http://localhost:8180/confluence
                ProxyPassReverse http://localhost:8180/confluence
        </Location>
</VirtualHost>
That config runs just fine. I can access http://www.myhost.org/confluence/ w/o 
any problems.
But asa i specify
<VirtualHost my.ip.address:443>
SSLEngine on
SSLCertificateFile    /etc/ssl/certs/www.myhost.org.crt
SSLCertificateKeyFile /etc/ssl/certs/www.myhost.org.key

with the rest remaining the same, things get screwed up. Trying to access 
https://www.myhost.org/confluence/ I end up with http://
www.myhost.orgconfluence/ that naturally leads nowhere.

So the problem is that proxying to https gets the trailing domain name slash 
lost.
A I see no signs of misconfiguration, this is considered a bug.

creator: rpluem@apache.org
text:
I cannot reproduce this. But it is strange that in the ssl case you get
redirected to  http://www.myhost.orgconfluence/ instead of 
https://www.myhost.orgconfluence/. Has this been a typo and you just missed the
s of https or does confluence has its fingers in there?
Do you configure www.myhost.org somewhere inside confluence?

creator: gsmdib@gmail.com
text:
My bad. I get redirected to https naturally.
Yes, I set address inside confluence (which is correct), but as far as I
understand, things don't get down to Confluence and the backslash is lost
somewhere in redirection.
I run a Debian Etch installation with tomcat & httpd installed from packages.
